description: From the participle stem of Latin dēfaecāre (“to purify”), from de- and faex (“dreg, impurity”).

adjectives.description: defecate (comparative more defecate, superlative most defecate)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Freed from pollutants, dregs, lees, etc.; refined; purified.
examples: Till the soul be defecate from the dregs of sense.

verbs.description: defecate (third-person singular simple present defecates, present participle defecating, simple past and past participle defecated)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To excrete feces from one's bowels.
(now rare) To purify, to clean of dregs etc.
examples: Some are of opinion that such fat, standing waters make the best beer, and that seething doth defecate it […].

entries.meaning: (now rare, transitive) To purge; to pass (something) as excrement.
